natural problem: Find the constant $c$ such that the remainder when $2x+7$ divides $2x^3+cx^2-11x+39$ is $4$.
natural solution: \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &   & -x\left(\frac{7c-27+20}{2}\right) & 4  \\ \end{array} \]In the last step of the division, we have $39$ left as the constant term in our dividend and we need a remainder of $4$ at the end.

Since our divisor has a term of $7$, the only way to do this is if our quotient has $5$ which gives us  $7\cdot5=35$ to subtract from our dividend and get the right remainder. Then, we need the rest of our remainder to be $0$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 3 + c * x powr 2 - 11 * x + 39"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x mod Q x = 4"
shows  "c = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the constant $c$ such that the remainder when $2x+7$ divides $2x^3+cx^2-11x+39$ is $4$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 \[ \begin{array}{c|cc cc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & +\left(\frac{c-7}{2}\right)x & +5 \\ \cline{2-5} 2x+7 & 2x^3 &+cx^2 &- 11x &+ 39  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-2x^3} & -7x^2  \\  \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & (c-7)x^2 & -11x  \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & -(c-7)x^2 & -x(c-7)\left(\frac{7}{2}\right)   \\  \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &  0 & -x\left(\frac{7c-27}{2}\right) & + 39  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &   & -10x & -35  \\ \cline{4-5}
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &   & -x\left(\frac{7c-27+20}{2}\right) & 4  \\ \end{array} \]In the last step of the division, we have $39$ left as the constant term in our dividend and we need a remainder of $4$ at the end.
 Since our divisor has a term of $7$, the only way to do this is if our quotient has $5$ which gives us  $7\cdot5=35$ to subtract from our dividend and get the right remainder. Then, we need the rest of our remainder to be $0$.
 This means $$\frac{7c-27+20}{2} = 0$$which gives us $$c = \boxed{1}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 3 + c * x powr 2 - 11 * x + 39"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x mod Q x = 4"
shows  "c = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If $P(x) = 2x^3 + cx^2 - 11x + 39$ and $Q(x) = 2x + 7$, find the value of $c$ such that $P(x) \mod Q(x) = 4$ for all $x$. The final answer is $c = 1$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 3 + c * x powr 2 - 11 * x + 39"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * (2 * x powr 2 + 1) + 4"
shows  "c = 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the constant $c$ such that the remainder when $2x+7$ divides $2x^3+cx^2-11x+39$ is $4$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 \[ \begin{array}{c|cc cc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x^2} & +\left(\frac{c-7}{2}\right)x & +5 \\ \cline{2-5} 2x+7 & 2x^3 &+cx^2 &- 11x &+ 39  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-2x^3} & -7x^2  \\  \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & (c-7)x^2 & -11x  \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & -(c-7)x^2 & -x(c-7)\left(\frac{7}{2}\right)   \\  \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &  0 & -x\left(\frac{7c-27}{2}\right) & + 39  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &   & -10x & -35  \\ \cline{4-5}
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &   & -x\left(\frac{7c-27+20}{2}\right) & 4  \\ \end{array} \]In the last step of the division, we have $39$ left as the constant term in our dividend and we need a remainder of $4$ at the end.
 Since our divisor has a term of $7$, the only way to do this is if our quotient has $5$ which gives us  $7\cdot5=35$ to subtract from our dividend and get the right remainder. Then, we need the rest of our remainder to be $0$.
 This means $$\frac{7c-27+20}{2} = 0$$which gives us $$c = \boxed{1}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 3 + c * x powr 2 - 11 * x + 39"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * (2 * x powr 2 + 1) + 4"
shows  "c = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two polynomial functions $P(x) = 2x^3 + cx^2 - 11x + 39$ and $Q(x) = 2x + 7$, where $P(x)$ is a divisor of $Q(x)$. If $P(x) = Q(x) * (2x^2 + 1) + 4$, find the value of $c$. The final answer is $c = 1$.

 *)

theorem
fixes x c :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 3 + c * x powr 2 - 11 * x + 39"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 7"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = 4"
shows  "c = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that the cubic function $P(x) = 2x^3 + cx^2 - 11x + 39$ for all $x$ and the linear function $Q(x) = 2x + 7$ for all $x$, find the value of $c$ such that the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $Q(x)$ is 4. The final answer is $c = 1$.
